title: Welcome to SNOMED International's Prospective Member Assessment Tool
subtitle: The SNOMED International Prospective Member Assessment Tool is designed to help Vendors, Members (National Release Centers), and User Organizations evaluate their progress in adopting and integrating SNOMED CT. This tool provides structured insights into implementation maturity, highlighting strengths and areas for improvement.

front.text: Identify gaps, gain insights, align with best practices, and advance SNOMED CT adoption—tailored for vendors, members, and user organizations.

items.title: Identify Gaps
items.text: Assess implementation challenges and pinpoint areas needing further development.

items.title: Obtain actionable
items.text: Insights – Supports continuous improvement and governance.

items.title: Align with Best Practices
items.text: Benchmark your progress against internationally recognized standards.

items.title: Tailored for Different Stakeholders
items.text: Designed to support key stakeholders in their SNOMED CT journey.

front.text: Assess key areas, receive a maturity score, gain improvement insights, and generate a report to enhance SNOMED CT implementation and collaboration.

items.title: Select Key Process Areas
items.text: Choose the areas most relevant to your role and implementation needs.

items.title: Complete the Assessment
items.text: Answer structured questions across selected key process areas.

items.title: Receive a Maturity Score
items.text: Get a clear view of your current implementation maturity level.

items.title: Download and Share Your Report
items.text: Generate a detailed report which can be stored for internal use or shared.

front.text: Tailored assessments for vendors, members, and user organizations to evaluate SNOMED CT integration, adoption, and clinical use.

items.title: Vendors
items.text: Assess SNOMED CT integration within healthcare software and applications.

items.title: Members
items.text: (National Release Centers) – Evaluate national or regional SNOMED CT adoption and management strategies.

items.title: User Organizations
items.text: Analyze SNOMED CT use within healthcare systems, EHRs, and clinical workflows.

stakeHolders.name: Prospective member
stakeHolders.description: A country that is not yet a member

options.text: Vision Only: Strategy is a high-level PDF with no legal weight.
Guidelines: Standards are recommended in technical notes; non-compliance has no penalty.
Technical Norms: Specific regulations exist but enforcement is weak or voluntary.
Binding: Decrees/Resolutions mandate the standard; non-compliant software is banned.

questions.name: Government
questions.question: Level of strength of digital health regulations

options.text: Fragmented: MoH governs public hospitals only; massive silos exist.
Coordinated: Committees exist to discuss standards but lack power.
Federated: Sub-sectors agree to a shared framework, but implementation varies.
Centralized: A Digital Health Authority has legal jurisdiction over all sectors.

questions.name: Data protection
questions.question: Existence and strength of data protection policies

options.text: None: Privacy relies on general ethics; no digital laws.
Restrictive: GDPR-style laws exist but block data sharing.
Adaptable: Laws are being amended to allow digital health records.
Enabling: Laws explicitly define portability and interoperability rights.

kpas.name: Financial and administrative
kpas.description: Existence of processes for external payments and level of financial sustainability

questions.name: Payment mechanism
questions.question: Does the Country have processes to make payments to external organizations

options.text: Blocked: Anti-corruption laws prevent international payments.
Ad-Hoc: Payments require complex, one-off exceptions.
Indirect: Payments routed through third parties (IDB/UN).
Cleared: Direct administrative channel exists for "Membership Fees".

questions.name: Sustainability
questions.question: The country have a multi-year budgeting for Membership fee

options.text: Sporadic: Relies 100% on external grants (IDB/World Bank).
Project-Based: Funding is tied to a specific project (e.g., EHR rollout).
Hybrid: Domestic funds cover ops; innovation needs loans.
Dedicated: Multi-year national budget line item.

questions.name: NRC capacity
questions.question: Existence of skilled personnel and plan to implement an NRC

options.text: None: IT managed by generalists; no terminology skills.
Passive: Identified personnel with terminology interest and skills.
Developing: Team is identified and training; assessing local needs.
Operational: Planned implementation of a NRC with trained personnel

questions.name: Legacy data
questions.question: How is the country managing the legacy records

options.text: None: Paper records or unstructured PDFs.
Digitizing: Scanning paper to PDF (still unstructured).
Day Forward: New records are coded; old ones archived.
Automated: Mapping projects ingest legacy text into codes.

questions.name: Vendor ecosystem
questions.question: Regulations on interoperability for commercial digital health records

options.text: Legacy: In-house/proprietary systems; no export capability.
Resistant: Vendors ask for standards but use local codes.
Transitioning: Vendors participating in pilots/Connectathons.
Certified: Vendors must pass "Interoperability Tests" to sell.

kpas.name: Human capital
kpas.description: How is the human capital engaged with the adoption of SNOMED CT

questions.name: Expertise
questions.question: The team is aware on the distinctions between Classifications and Terminologies and their coexistence

options.text: Immature: Staff have no information on the differences and complementarities of SNOMED CT (Clinical) and ICD (Stats).
Academic: A few champions know the difference; no teams.
Training: Professionals taking courses; community forming.
Practicing: MoH has a "Coexistence Strategy" for ICD/SNOMED. Community of knowledge stablished.
Brain Drain: No developers; reliance on foreign consultants.
Outsourced: Technical work is contracted to agencies (PAHO).
Upskilling: Universities starting to offer informatics modules.
Homegrown: Steady stream of local devs knowing FHIR+SNOMED.

questions.name: User acceptance
questions.question: Level of acceptance of the use of SNOMED CT by users

options.text: Resistant: Doctors see data entry as admin burden.
Skeptical: "Click fatigue" is a major complaint.
Adopting: Younger clinicians use apps; older ones resist.
Invisible: Coding happens in background; health application's UI is user-friendly. Clinical champions
